aws::graph::propositions: # Australian Lithium Discovery and Investment Announcement
The Australian government announced the discovery of the world's largest lithium deposit.
The lithium deposit is located in the remote Pilbara region of Western Australia.
The Australian government announced a $15 billion investment program.
The investment program aims to establish Australia as the global leader in battery materials processing and refining.
The lithium deposit spans over 200 square kilometers.
The lithium deposit contains an estimated 50 million tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent.
The lithium deposit could potentially double global known reserves.
Initial geological surveys suggest the deposit could supply global lithium demand for the next 30 years.
The lithium deposit offers a potential solution to critical battery material shortages.
Battery material shortages are currently constraining renewable energy expansion worldwide.
Anthony Albanese is the Prime Minister of Australia.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced the discovery during a press conference.
The press conference was held in Perth.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese stated "This discovery represents a game-changing moment for Australia and the global clean energy transition."

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese stated "We're not just going to export raw materials – we're building a complete domestic supply chain that will make Australia the battery materials superpower of the 21st century."
Australia plans to build a complete domestic supply chain for battery materials.

metadata.header_path: /Australia Announces Massive Lithium Discovery and $15 Billion Processing Investment/
/Australia Announces Massive Lithium Discovery and $15 Billion Processing Investment/

text:
## News Report

The Australian government today announced the discovery of what experts believe is the world's largest lithium deposit, located in the remote Pilbara region of Western Australia, alongside a massive $15 billion investment program to establish the country as the global leader in battery materials processing and refining.

The newly discovered deposit, spanning over 200 square kilometers, contains an estimated 50 million tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent, potentially doubling global known reserves. Initial geological surveys suggest the deposit could supply global lithium demand for the next 30 years, offering a potential solution to the critical battery material shortages currently constraining renewable energy expansion worldwide.

"This discovery represents a game-changing moment for Australia and the global clean energy transition," announced Prime Minister Anthony Albanese during a press conference in Perth. "We're not just going to export raw materials – we're building a complete domestic supply chain that will make Australia the battery materials superpower of the 21st century."
